trans-unit.source: Network Architecture Overview of App Service Environments
trans-unit.target: Network Architecture Overview of App Service Environments

trans-unit.source: Architectural overview of network topology ofApp Service Environments.
trans-unit.target: Architectural overview of network topology ofApp Service Environments.

trans-unit.source: Network Architecture Overview of App Service Environments
trans-unit.target: Network Architecture Overview of App Service Environments

trans-unit.source: Introduction
trans-unit.target: Introduction

trans-unit.source: App Service Environments are always created within a subnet of a <link><linkText>virtual network[virtualnetwork]</linkText><title></title></link>, apps running in an App Service Environment can communicate with private endpoints located within the same virtual network topology.
trans-unit.target: App Service Environments are always created within a subnet of a <link><linkText>virtual network[virtualnetwork]</linkText><title></title></link>, apps running in an App Service Environment can communicate with private endpoints located within the same virtual network topology.

trans-unit.source: Since customers may lock down parts of their virtual network infrastructure, it is important to understand the types of network communication flows that occur with an App Service Environment.
trans-unit.target: Since customers may lock down parts of their virtual network infrastructure, it is important to understand the types of network communication flows that occur with an App Service Environment.

trans-unit.source: General Network Flow
trans-unit.target: General Network Flow

trans-unit.source: An App Service Environment always has a public virtual IP address (VIP).
trans-unit.target: An App Service Environment always has a public virtual IP address (VIP).

trans-unit.source: All inbound traffic arrives on that public VIP including HTTP and HTTPS traffic for apps, as well as other traffic for FTP, remote debugging functionality, and Azure management operations.
trans-unit.target: All inbound traffic arrives on that public VIP including HTTP and HTTPS traffic for apps, as well as other traffic for FTP, remote debugging functionality, and Azure management operations.

trans-unit.source: For a full list of the specific ports (both required and optional) that are available on the public VIP see the article on <link><linkText>controlling inbound traffic[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link> to an App Service Environment.
trans-unit.target: For a full list of the specific ports (both required and optional) that are available on the public VIP see the article on <link><linkText>controlling inbound traffic[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link> to an App Service Environment.

trans-unit.source: The diagram below shows an overview of the various inbound and outbound network flows:
trans-unit.target: The diagram below shows an overview of the various inbound and outbound network flows:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>General Network Flows</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>General Network Flows</linkText>

trans-unit.source: An App Service Environment can communicate with a variety of private customer endpoints.
trans-unit.target: An App Service Environment can communicate with a variety of private customer endpoints.

trans-unit.source: For example, apps running in the App Service Environment can connect to database server(s) running on IaaS virtual machines in the same virtual network topology.
trans-unit.target: For example, apps running in the App Service Environment can connect to database server(s) running on IaaS virtual machines in the same virtual network topology.

trans-unit.source: App Service Environments also communicate with Sql DB and Azure Storage resources necessary for managing and operating an App Service Environment.
trans-unit.target: App Service Environments also communicate with Sql DB and Azure Storage resources necessary for managing and operating an App Service Environment.

trans-unit.source: Some of the Sql and Storage resources that an App Service Environment communicates with are located in the same region as the App Service Environment, while others are located in remote Azure regions.
trans-unit.target: Some of the Sql and Storage resources that an App Service Environment communicates with are located in the same region as the App Service Environment, while others are located in remote Azure regions.

trans-unit.source: As a result, outbound connectivity to the Internet is always required for an App Service Environment to function properly.
trans-unit.target: As a result, outbound connectivity to the Internet is always required for an App Service Environment to function properly.

trans-unit.source: Since an App Service Environment is deployed in a subnet, network security groups can be used to control inbound traffic to the subnet.
trans-unit.target: Since an App Service Environment is deployed in a subnet, network security groups can be used to control inbound traffic to the subnet.

trans-unit.source: For details on how to control inbound traffic to an App Service Environment, see the following <link><linkText>article[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details on how to control inbound traffic to an App Service Environment, see the following <link><linkText>article[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: For details on how to allow outbound Internet connectivity from an App Service Environment, see the following article about working with <link><linkText>Express Route[expressroute]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For details on how to allow outbound Internet connectivity from an App Service Environment, see the following article about working with <link><linkText>Express Route[expressroute]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The same approach described in the article applies when working with Site-to-Site connectivity and using forced tunneling.
trans-unit.target: The same approach described in the article applies when working with Site-to-Site connectivity and using forced tunneling.

trans-unit.source: Outbound Network Addresses
trans-unit.target: Outbound Network Addresses

trans-unit.source: When an App Service Environment makes outbound calls, an IP Address is always associated with the outbound calls.
trans-unit.target: When an App Service Environment makes outbound calls, an IP Address is always associated with the outbound calls.

trans-unit.source: The specific IP address that is used depends on whether the endpoint being called is located within the virtual network topology, or outside of the virtual network topology.
trans-unit.target: The specific IP address that is used depends on whether the endpoint being called is located within the virtual network topology, or outside of the virtual network topology.

trans-unit.source: If the endpoint being called is outside of the virtual network topology, then the outbound address (aka the outbound NAT address) that is used is the public VIP of the App Service Environment.
trans-unit.target: If the endpoint being called is outside of the virtual network topology, then the outbound address (aka the outbound NAT address) that is used is the public VIP of the App Service Environment.

trans-unit.source: This address can be found in the portal user interface for the App Service Environment (note: UX pending).
trans-unit.target: This address can be found in the portal user interface for the App Service Environment (note: UX pending).

trans-unit.source: This address can also be determined by creating an app in the App Service Environment, and then performing an nslookup on the app's address.
trans-unit.target: This address can also be determined by creating an app in the App Service Environment, and then performing an nslookup on the app's address.

trans-unit.source: The resultant IP address is the both the public VIP, as well as the App Service Environment's outbound NAT address.
trans-unit.target: The resultant IP address is the both the public VIP, as well as the App Service Environment's outbound NAT address.

trans-unit.source: If the endpoint being called is inside of the virtual network topology, the outbound address of the calling app will be the internal IP address of the individual compute resource running the app.
trans-unit.target: If the endpoint being called is inside of the virtual network topology, the outbound address of the calling app will be the internal IP address of the individual compute resource running the app.

trans-unit.source: However there is not a persistent mapping of virtual network internal IP addresses to apps.
trans-unit.target: However there is not a persistent mapping of virtual network internal IP addresses to apps.

trans-unit.source: Apps can move around across different compute resources, and the pool of available compute resources in an App Service Environment can change due to scaling operations.
trans-unit.target: Apps can move around across different compute resources, and the pool of available compute resources in an App Service Environment can change due to scaling operations.

trans-unit.source: However, since an App Service Environment is always located within a subnet, you are guaranteed that the internal IP address of a compute resource running an app will always lie within the CIDR range of the subnet.
trans-unit.target: However, since an App Service Environment is always located within a subnet, you are guaranteed that the internal IP address of a compute resource running an app will always lie within the CIDR range of the subnet.

trans-unit.source: As a result, when fine-grained ACLs or network security groups are used to secure access to other endpoints within the virtual network, the subnet range containing the App Service Environment needs to be granted access.
trans-unit.target: As a result, when fine-grained ACLs or network security groups are used to secure access to other endpoints within the virtual network, the subnet range containing the App Service Environment needs to be granted access.

trans-unit.source: The following diagram shows these concepts in more detail:
trans-unit.target: The following diagram shows these concepts in more detail:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Outbound Network Addresses</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Outbound Network Addresses</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the above diagram:
trans-unit.target: In the above diagram:

trans-unit.source: Since the public VIP of the App Service Environment is 192.23.1.2, that is the outbound IP address used when making calls to "Internet" endpoints.
trans-unit.target: Since the public VIP of the App Service Environment is 192.23.1.2, that is the outbound IP address used when making calls to "Internet" endpoints.

trans-unit.source: The CIDR range of the containing subnet for the App Service Environment is 10.0.1.0/26.
trans-unit.target: The CIDR range of the containing subnet for the App Service Environment is 10.0.1.0/26.

trans-unit.source: Other endpoints within the same virtual network infrastructure will see calls from apps as originating from somewhere within this address range.
trans-unit.target: Other endpoints within the same virtual network infrastructure will see calls from apps as originating from somewhere within this address range.

trans-unit.source: Calls Between App Service Environments
trans-unit.target: Calls Between App Service Environments

trans-unit.source: A more complex scenario can occur if you deploy multiple App Service Environments in the same virtual network, and make outbound calls from one App Service Environment to another App Service Environment.
trans-unit.target: A more complex scenario can occur if you deploy multiple App Service Environments in the same virtual network, and make outbound calls from one App Service Environment to another App Service Environment.

trans-unit.source: These types of cross App Service Environment calls will also be treated as "Internet" calls.
trans-unit.target: These types of cross App Service Environment calls will also be treated as "Internet" calls.

trans-unit.source: As an example using the App Service Environment above with the outbound IP address of 192.23.1.2: if an app running on the App Service Environment makes an outbound call to an app running on a second App Service Environment located in the same virtual network, the outbound calls arriving on the second App Service Environment will show as originating from 192.23.1.2 (i.e. not the subnet address range of the first App Service Environment).
trans-unit.target: As an example using the App Service Environment above with the outbound IP address of 192.23.1.2: if an app running on the App Service Environment makes an outbound call to an app running on a second App Service Environment located in the same virtual network, the outbound calls arriving on the second App Service Environment will show as originating from 192.23.1.2 (i.e. not the subnet address range of the first App Service Environment).

trans-unit.source: Even though calls between different App Service Environments are treated as "Internet" calls, when both App Service Environments are located in the same Azure region the network traffic will remain on the regional Azure network and will not phyically flow over the public Internet.
trans-unit.target: Even though calls between different App Service Environments are treated as "Internet" calls, when both App Service Environments are located in the same Azure region the network traffic will remain on the regional Azure network and will not phyically flow over the public Internet.

trans-unit.source: As a result you can use a network security group on the subnet of the second App Service Environment to only allow inbound calls from 192.23.1.2, thus ensuring secure communication between the App Service Environments.
trans-unit.target: As a result you can use a network security group on the subnet of the second App Service Environment to only allow inbound calls from 192.23.1.2, thus ensuring secure communication between the App Service Environments.

trans-unit.source: Additional Links and Information
trans-unit.target: Additional Links and Information

trans-unit.source: Details on inbound ports used by App Service Environments and using network security groups to control inbound traffic is available <link><linkText>here[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Details on inbound ports used by App Service Environments and using network security groups to control inbound traffic is available <link><linkText>here[controllinginboundtraffic]</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Details on using user defined routes to grant outbound Internet access to App Service Environments is available in this <link><linkText>article[expressroute]</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: Details on using user defined routes to grant outbound Internet access to App Service Environments is available in this <link><linkText>article[expressroute]</linkText><title></title></link>.
